Federal Funding--Breakdown For Hopkins
The relationship between Washington and Hopkins--the government's restrictions on research funding, the University's lobbying
techniques and the incredible bureaucracy between them--is the
subject of the second report on federal funding.
On Tuesday, the outlook for the future will be detailed. The
information was compiled and written by Mark Reutter and Ted
Rohrlich.

Rules Snarl Funds
says
the
Everyone
University could not exist as
a graduate institution without
federal grants and contracts,
but neither could much of its
mushrooming administrative
bureacracy.
The procedure for getting
federal funding for a project
of
a
maze
involves
regulations, which are often
contradictory on an agency to
agency basis.
First, a faculty member
initiates a proposal. Then,
the Sponsored Research
Officer of the professor's
Division (for Arts and
Sciences, Donald McLeon
goes over the application to
make certain the professor
has
followed
agency
requirements.
Then, the application is
forwarded to the department
chairman and then to the
Dean for approval, and then
McLeod's office makes a final
check for "content."
Once in Washington, the
grant is reviewed by an
impartial panel which rates
the project on a scale from 1
to 10, decides on the duration
of the grant and its budget.
As a final step, the agency
in question reviews the findings of its review board.
"They monitor the grants
from beginning to end," said
McLeod.
Because
the
federal
government audits its accounts thoroughly, and
University
administraters
don't like to be caught with
their pants down, they run
checks and doublechecks for
mistakes and three audit
checks for cheating.
In the process of setting up
their audit, the federal
government agency in charge
(for this geographic area,
HEW) negotiates a rebate
with the University.
By law, Hopkins must
share in the costs of research
grants, contributing on the
average ten per cent of the
dollar-value of the grant.
But it gets money back as
well. This money goes to
cover indirect costs incurred
by the recipient insititution.
These costs are computed as
a percentage of the salary
monies which make up the
greatest chunk of the grant.
The current rebate rate for
Arts and Sciences is 46.4 per
cent. It helps to pay the
persons
salaries
of
peripherally involved in the
funded project, but who
devote part of their time to
making the system work-such
as
department
secretaries who type the
manuscripts, and comptroller's office personnel:
The

University

is

prohibited by law from
making a profit on the rebate
and federal auditors play a
sharp watchdog role.
Three years ago, Benjamin
Willis, acting VP for Administration, recalled, "they
took us to task for having in
their view inadequate purchasing methods."
What
resulted was the central
purchasing office.
"It takes us twice as much
manpower to administer a
grant or contract from the
government as from anybody
else," Willis said.

Money Comes at a Price
The benefit of government
funding is in dollars and
cents.
Hopkins' enormous flow of
grants and contracts attracts
some of the nation's best
scientists eager to work in
such a research environment.
"In a university like
Hopkins, money from the
government is a must," said
Dr. Phillip Hartman, Biology.
"Without it I might not be
here and many of our
graduate students wouldn't
be."
Federal funding helps
make professors' salaries
more competitive with industries.
Federal funding pays for
much of the graduate training
programs and research
equipment.

But federal funding comes
at a price--in the form of
technical
political and
restrictions.
Dr. Peter Rossi, Social
Relations remembered,
"There have been grants of
mine turned down because

topics." He said that in the
early 1960's his proposed
study on race relations was
rejected until the subject
became more politically
fashionable.
Federal money recently
has also shyed away from
basic research. The federal
Office of Education, for
example, now only funds
specific research usually
concerned with a set age
group unlike its old interest in
basic research.

Kent Moratorium
The repression going on now at Kent State should be
the concern of students everywhere. The Ohio grand
jury, by indicting 25 students and exonerating the
National Guard, is trying to justify the slaughter of four
students last May. The warning in this bid to stifle
freedom is clear: they can get us for anything they
want.

the trigger-happy response of the Ohio National Guard
to protests. Furthermore, both the Scranton Commission and the FBI strongly condemned the National
Guard. So, by somehow making a clear case of government abuse the fault of the students, the Ohio grand jury
hopes to frighten other students away from protest, and
curb the traditional liberty of universities. This scareand-punish response has already been used by the

leaders after the Chicago police riots. The pattern will
undoubtedly continue, until every outbreak of mindless
state violence will be followed by the arrest of the victims.

approach to protestors, we can expect only more
political trials and more threats against our liberties.

this danger is greatest. We cannot permit a repeat of the
McCarthy era, when careers were broken and the
Constitution ignored in the hysterical drive to crush the
Reds. And a start towards resisting the new madness is
the call by Kent State student leaders for a national
moratorium today.

back this moratorium as a show of support for the indicted students. Also, we join in the call by the Kent
student and faculty organizations for a Federal grand
jury investigation into the events of last May. Perhaps,
by standing together, we can begin to stem the angry
tide of repression.

Fight the Fed. Monster
By MARK DERR
It would seem that in a period which sees
unrest prevalent throughout the world and a
widespread questioning of the nature and
role of the university in society there should
be a serious debate concerning the future of
The John Hopkins University.
But, there is no such debate. We, the
citizens of this nation and members of the
"Hopkins Community", have for many
years now heard talk on the part of liberal
intellectuals and others of the need for reordering national priorities and we have
seen some small movement in that direction
-- at least now more people are talking about,
that idea.
But we see no large scale discussion within
this particular segment of society, which
seems to be more closely tied to the national
superstructure than any of us had assumed,
concerning a reordering of its own priorities.
It is my belief -- and I hope that of others -that on the eve of its 100th birthday the
members of the Hopkins community should
look into the present structure of the
University, which now receives 53% of its
budget from the Federal Government
(News- Letter, 10/ 20), with respect to the
way it is run and the nature and extent of its
committment both to teaching and to
research. We should undertake this investigation in an attempt to determine the
direction it should follow in the future.
Contractor and Slumlord
This University was established in 1876 for
a purpose, that being one of education past
the B.A. and B.S. and academic research.
Since its founding it has undergone many
changes. It has become a military contractor and slumlord. In a word, this
University has become a somewhat
glamorized business -- and a big business at
that.
Not all of the changes that occured were in
the realm of pursuing contracts. Some were
instituted in the belief that they would further the cause of higher education "in these
United States." Despite the nature or
reasons for the many changes which have
occured, it seems that the most notable in
recent years is this University's surrender of
its freedom to the Government.
That is to say that the University has
unwittingly and now, it seems, willingly sold
its soul to Mammon and Mars. Regardless
of our opinions concerning these changes we
should all commit ourselves to a critical
examination of our reasons for existence as
a University community.
We should commit ourselves to an attempt
to determine where this University stands in
relation to society as a whole and its various
segments, in relation to the federal government, and where each group in the com-

munity - undergraduates, graduate
studends, trustees, faculty, administrators,
employees, and others - stand in relation to
the whole.
January Minimester
I propose that the January Minimester be
set aside for a true educational experience. I
propose that the University call for a month
of seminars and convocations to be attended
by everyone associated with the University
and interested in its future.
That means that representatives of the
government - state, local, and federal -- the
trustees, administrators, faculty members,
students, employees, and all others
associated with this University would be
invited to attend and participate on an equal
basis. Any final proposals should be ratified
by the entire University Community in
accordance with the democratic principle of
"one man, one vote."
The purpose of this month of debate would
hopefully be to come up with proposals the
University could pursue in the future, if it
should so choose. Of course, it is possible
that the oligarchy which rules this
University may choose not to allow the
University - that is the members of the
community - to attempt to determine its own
future.
Perhaps they would rather see it die
noiselessly. By this I mean that they may
choose to sit back and watch the University
be swallowed by the Federal Monster - perhaps we all would. After a month of
debate it may be decided that the University
is destined to fall into the jaws of that beast.
If such a decision is reached, it must then
be decided whether the University should
bow to the inevitable, in which case steps
should be taken to abolish the student body
and change the name to The Johns Hopkins
Research Institute, or whether it should sit
back, raise ulcers, and pray for a better day.
Of course, if it really wanted to be radical
and assert its independence, it could fight -God forbid! If we fight the monster now,
chances are he will slaughter us right away;
whereas, if we bow to his demands, he
might,"by the grace of God," decide to keep
us as a pet.
On second thought, perhaps we should not
meet, because we might decide to fight the
Federal Monster, and a few others as well.
No, perhaps we should continue to allow
ourselves to be swept along by the tide of
circumstances. We might get hurt, if we
dare to say no, if we attempt to seize control.
Why should we not continue to abolish one
department after another in the name of
efficiency and economy?

Mark Derr is a Junior, majoring in English.

Kent Moratorium
The repression going on now at Kent State should be
the concern of students everywhere. The Ohio grand
jury, by indicting 25 students and exonerating the
National Guard, is trying to justify the slaughter of four
students last May. The warning in this bid to stifle
freedom is clear: they can get us for anything they
want.

the trigger-happy response of the Ohio National Guard
to protests. Furthermore, both the Scranton Commission and the FBI strongly condemned the National
Guard. So, by somehow making a clear case of government abuse the fault of the students, the Ohio grand jury
hopes to frighten other students away from protest, and
curb the traditional liberty of universities. This scareand-punish response has already been used by the

leaders after the Chicago police riots. The pattern will
undoubtedly continue, until every outbreak of mindless
state violence will be followed by the arrest of the victims.

approach to protestors, we can expect only more
political trials and more threats against our liberties.

this danger is greatest. We cannot permit a repeat of the
McCarthy era, when careers were broken and the
Constitution ignored in the hysterical drive to crush the
Reds. And a start towards resisting the new madness is
the call by Kent State student leaders for a national
moratorium today.

back this moratorium as a show of support for the indicted students. Also, we join in the call by the Kent
student and faculty organizations for a Federal grand
jury investigation into the events of last May. Perhaps,
by standing together, we can begin to stem the angry
tide of repression.

Fight the Fed. Monster
By MARK DERR
It would seem that in a period which sees
unrest prevalent throughout the world and a
widespread questioning of the nature and
role of the university in society there should
be a serious debate concerning the future of
The John Hopkins University.
But, there is no such debate. We, the
citizens of this nation and members of the
"Hopkins Community", have for many
years now heard talk on the part of liberal
intellectuals and others of the need for reordering national priorities and we have
seen some small movement in that direction
-- at least now more people are talking about,
that idea.
But we see no large scale discussion within
this particular segment of society, which
seems to be more closely tied to the national
superstructure than any of us had assumed,
concerning a reordering of its own priorities.
It is my belief -- and I hope that of others -that on the eve of its 100th birthday the
members of the Hopkins community should
look into the present structure of the
University, which now receives 53% of its
budget from the Federal Government
(News- Letter, 10/ 20), with respect to the
way it is run and the nature and extent of its
committment both to teaching and to
research. We should undertake this investigation in an attempt to determine the
direction it should follow in the future.
Contractor and Slumlord
This University was established in 1876 for
a purpose, that being one of education past
the B.A. and B.S. and academic research.
Since its founding it has undergone many
changes. It has become a military contractor and slumlord. In a word, this
University has become a somewhat
glamorized business -- and a big business at
that.
Not all of the changes that occured were in
the realm of pursuing contracts. Some were
instituted in the belief that they would further the cause of higher education "in these
United States." Despite the nature or
reasons for the many changes which have
occured, it seems that the most notable in
recent years is this University's surrender of
its freedom to the Government.
That is to say that the University has
unwittingly and now, it seems, willingly sold
its soul to Mammon and Mars. Regardless
of our opinions concerning these changes we
should all commit ourselves to a critical
examination of our reasons for existence as
a University community.
We should commit ourselves to an attempt
to determine where this University stands in
relation to society as a whole and its various
segments, in relation to the federal government, and where each group in the com-

munity - undergraduates, graduate
studends, trustees, faculty, administrators,
employees, and others - stand in relation to
the whole.
January Minimester
I propose that the January Minimester be
set aside for a true educational experience. I
propose that the University call for a month
of seminars and convocations to be attended
by everyone associated with the University
and interested in its future.
That means that representatives of the
government - state, local, and federal -- the
trustees, administrators, faculty members,
students, employees, and all others
associated with this University would be
invited to attend and participate on an equal
basis. Any final proposals should be ratified
by the entire University Community in
accordance with the democratic principle of
"one man, one vote."
The purpose of this month of debate would
hopefully be to come up with proposals the
University could pursue in the future, if it
should so choose. Of course, it is possible
that the oligarchy which rules this
University may choose not to allow the
University - that is the members of the
community - to attempt to determine its own
future.
Perhaps they would rather see it die
noiselessly. By this I mean that they may
choose to sit back and watch the University
be swallowed by the Federal Monster - perhaps we all would. After a month of
debate it may be decided that the University
is destined to fall into the jaws of that beast.
If such a decision is reached, it must then
be decided whether the University should
bow to the inevitable, in which case steps
should be taken to abolish the student body
and change the name to The Johns Hopkins
Research Institute, or whether it should sit
back, raise ulcers, and pray for a better day.
Of course, if it really wanted to be radical
and assert its independence, it could fight -God forbid! If we fight the monster now,
chances are he will slaughter us right away;
whereas, if we bow to his demands, he
might,"by the grace of God," decide to keep
us as a pet.
On second thought, perhaps we should not
meet, because we might decide to fight the
Federal Monster, and a few others as well.
No, perhaps we should continue to allow
ourselves to be swept along by the tide of
circumstances. We might get hurt, if we
dare to say no, if we attempt to seize control.
Why should we not continue to abolish one
department after another in the name of
efficiency and economy?

Mark Derr is a Junior, majoring in English.

Pitts: Down But Not Out

By JAY LENROW
As many students are by now aware,
sophomore quarterback Jim Pitts was
seriously injured this past Saturday in a
football game against Haverford College.
Because of the pounding he received, he
was in surgery late into Saturday evening
and had his spleen and one kidney removed.
This has effectively ended his sports career.
Jim played his high school ball at Kenwood
High School in Baltimore County. When I
contacted his old coach Charles Geis, the
feelings toward Jim were essentially the
same as voiced by almost every other person
who knows him. Geis had nothing but praise
for his former starting quarterback.
Pitts came to Kenwood in his junior year
and soon became the starting varsity
quarterback. He also lettered in basketball
and baseball that year.
In his senior year, Pitts was injured after
playing only three games but recovered in
time to letter in basketball and to switch to
the varsity lacrosse team.
The general impression given by Pitts'
coaches was that he has been the team
leader in most of the sports that he has
played. He was the recipient of the Blanch
Drenna Award, given annually to the outstanding senior athlete of Kenwood in his
three year sports career.
• As Coach Charles Geis remarked, "He
may not have been the best athlete that ever
played for me, but he was certainly one of
the finest people I have ever met."
As a freshman last year, Jim participated
in football and lacrosse. He was an outstanding quarterback and punter and was
one of the reasons that the Baby Jays did so

well last year. On lacrosse he was one of the
mainstays of a fine frosh team and was
counted on heavily to play on the varsity this
year.
Pitts came to football practice this fall
with a good attitude and it was quickly
evident that he would be a threat to senior
Bob Pfieffer as a quarterback. Pitts started
the first game but was eventually switched
to half-back where he was needed more.
When speaking about him, Coach Alex
Sotir stated, "Jim's most valua., • assets
were not his ability but the enthusiasm he
brought to the sport. As well as he did during
his career, he could never do more than his
enthusiasm was able to accomplish."
Hopkins' athletic trainer, known to most
people as Brandy, summed upr ' -general
feelings when he said, "There are a lot ol
other people I would rather see get hurt than
Pitts."
The entire unfortunate incident could have
been avoided if there had been referees with
some semblance of competence. Throughout
the entire game they seemed to turn their
backs on serious infractions of the rules
promulgated by the Ha verford squad. In the
case of Jim Pitts he was hit twice after the
referees had blown the play dead in clear
violation of all rules of fair play and sportsmanship. The result, as is now known, was
serious injury.
We can only ask that Marshall Turner as
the Director of Athletics sees to it that the
referees used in Saturday's game are never
used again and that he write a letter to the
Middle-Atlantic Conference stating exactly
wily Hopkins won't employ them any more.
